707113f-b.text:
(1)
Ave. U., south side, west of Gerritsen Creek, sho ing a house in the foreground, which is in the line of Burnett Street. At some future date it will be either moved or demolished because of the extensiou of Burnett Street. When the streets are finally cut into this property, the Whitney house which will no longer be in existence would, if standing be in Marine Park Property at the N.E. corner of Ave. V. and Burnett
Street, and the barn would be on the S.W. oorner.
August 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, another view.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(3)
The same, showing the mill in a view south.
February 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(4)
The same, a view south east, showing in the background, the disposal tanks of one of the New York City sewage plants on Ave. W.
September 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
707113f-b.folder: Ave. U & Van Sicklen St., Brooklyn, NY
707113f-b.original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.

707106f-c.text:
(1)
Ave. U (general view) as seen from Ave. S, and across the filled land that once was Gerritsen Creek. This view is south, and shows Gerritsen's Mill just beyond the bridge; which is a portion of Ave. U. This area,
today, 1937, is part of Marine Park.
May 1927.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
A view northward across the area shown in No. 1. Ave U forms the
foreground.
February 26, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The samNWe, a more extensise view.
February 26, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(4)
The same, further south, showing Gravesend beyond Geriitsen Creek.
May 1927.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

707109f-b.text:
Ave. U., south side, west of Gerritsen Creek. This property
dating from a grant of 1645 to Hugh Gerritsen, has been transferred by  wills to the following owners:- Rem Gerritsen, Garret Gerritsen, and
from Sarauel Gerritsen, to Johannus Gerritsen, who in 1765 left it to
his son Samuel. He, in 1822, left it to his son John S. and hi: daughters, Jane and Elizabeth. In 1864, John Samuel Gerritsen left this
farm to Samuel J., who in turn left it in 1876 to Mary C., born 1822,
and Helen Van Brunt born 1824. I1 1864, Samuel J., sold what he did
not bequeath to his two daughters, to one Pothemus. All this property
in 1879, was purchased by Helen Van Brunt (Mrs. Stephen Harriman).
Her heirs conveyed it to William C. Whitney in 1899: and he restored
the mill to its original condition in 1900, and vastly improved the
house. The first mill was erected in 1656, this one was erected in
1831. Harry Payne Whitney was the last owner. This house and most of
the out buildings are on condemned property, which is to be used for
Marine Park.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
The same, the mill and house are to be demolished. The creekw4ll  be filled and will be a part of Marine Park.
May 12, 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
707109f-b.folder: Ave. U & Van Sicklen St., Brooklyn, NY
707109f-b.original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
